annotations.submitter_comment: Four mutant lines of Botrytis cinerea with high levels of resistance to fludioxonil were obtained in the laboratory by selection on fungicide-amended media. Resistance to fungicides were assessed on amended PDA plates.

extension.rangeDisplayName: Bos1+[WT level] Botrytis cinerea (Nj5-10) / wild type Fragaria ananassa (Unknown strain)

annotations.submitter_comment: All fludioxonil-resistant isolates were virulent on strawberry leaves; however, they caused significantly smaller lesions compared with the parental sensitive strains. Mycelial plugs of B. cinerea were placed on the adaxial side of strawberry leaves that had been previously wounded with a sterilized needle. After 5 days, the lesion diameter on each inoculated leaf was measured.

annotations.submitter_comment: All fludioxonil-resistant isolates were virulent on strawberry leaves; however, they caused significantly smaller lesions compared with the parental sensitive strains. Mycelial plugs of B. cinerea were placed on the adaxial side of strawberry leaves that had been previously wounded with a sterilized needle. After 5 days, the lesion diameter on each inoculated leaf was measured.
The mutant FgSch9Δ showed reduced aerial hyphae on potato dextrose agar (PDA), complete medium (CM) and minimum medium (MM) compared to the wild type PH-1.

A high percentage of FgSch9Δ conidia showed significantly delayed germination, failing to germinate after 3 or even 6 h of incubation in 2% sucrose. The mutant needed 9 h of incubation for complete germination whereas the wild type germinated after 3 h.
The average length of germinated conidial germ tube of the FgSch9Δ mutant was decreased dramatically than that of the wild-type PH-1 after 3 h, 6 h and 9 h of incubation in 2% sucrose.

Wheat heads were point-inoculated with conidial suspension of the wild-type PH-1 and mutant lines. Infected wheat heads were photographed 15 days after inoculation. Infection with wild-type PH-1 strain caused severe and well-dispersed scab symptoms on wheat heads.

extension.rangeDisplayName: FgSch9+[WT level] Fusarium graminearum (PH-1) / wild type Triticum aestivum (cv. Zimai 22)

annotations.submitter_comment: Wheat heads were point-inoculated with conidial suspension of the wild-type PH-1 and FgSch9Δ mutant strains. Infected wheat heads were photographed 15 days after inoculation. Scab symptoms generated by ΔFgSch9 were restricted to the inoculated spikelets and those in the immediate vicinity, in comparison to widespread symptoms caused by the wild type strain, indicating FgSch9 is required for full virulence of F. graminearum.

ΔFgSch9 revealed significantly increased sensitivity to osmotic stress generated by 0.5 or 1.0 M NaCl compared to the wild type strain PH-1. Comparisons were made on PDA amended without or with 0.2 M, 0.5 M, 1 M, 1.2 M NaCl. Mycelial growth inhibition was examined after each strain was incubated for 3 days on PDA.
ΔFgHog1 showed significantly increased sensitivity to osmotic stress.
FgSch9Δ Hog1Δ double mutant showed significantly increased sensitivity to osmotic stress, even more severe than that of the single FgSch9Δ and Hog1Δ mutants.
FgSch9Δ revealed increased resistance to the phenylpyrrole fungicide, fludioxonil, which targets the HOG pathway.
HOG1Δ revealed increased resistance to the phenylpyrrole fungicide, fludioxonil, which targets the HOG pathway.
FgSch9Δ Hog1Δ double mutant showed significantly increased resistance to the fungicide fludioxonil.

ΔFgSch9 exhibited increased sensitivity to oxidative stress generated by hydrogen peroxide. Sensitivity of F. graminearum strains to oxidative stress was tested on PDA amended without or with 0.02% (w/v) H2O2. Mycelial growth inhibition was examined after each strain was incubated for 3 days on PDA.

HOG1Δ exhibited increased sensitivity to oxidative stress generated by hydrogen peroxide. Sensitivity of F. graminearum strains to oxidative stress was tested on PDA amended without or with 0.02% (w/v) H2O2. Mycelial growth inhibition was examined after each strain was incubated for 3 days on PDA.

FgSch9Δ HOG1Δ double mutant exhibited increased sensitivity to oxidative stress generated by hydrogen peroxide. Sensitivity of F. graminearum strains to oxidative stress was tested on PDA amended without or with 0.02% (w/v) H2O2. Mycelial growth inhibition was examined after each strain was incubated for 3 days on PDA.

ΔFgSch9 exhibited increased sensitivity to the cell wall-damaging agent congo red. Sensitivity of F. graminearum strains was tested on PDA amended without or with 0.02% (w/v) congo red. Mycelial growth inhibition was examined after each strain was incubated for 3 days on PDA.

HOG1Δ exhibited increased sensitivity to the cell wall-damaging agent congo red. Sensitivity of F. graminearum strains was tested on PDA amended without or with 0.02% (w/v) congo red. Mycelial growth inhibition was examined after each strain was incubated for 3 days on PDA.

FgSch9Δ HOG1Δ exhibited increased sensitivity to the cell wall-damaging agent congo red. Sensitivity of F. graminearum strains was tested on PDA amended without or with 0.02% (w/v) congo red. Mycelial growth inhibition was examined after each strain was incubated for 3 days on PDA.

ΔFgSch9 exhibited increased sensitivity to the cell wall-damaging agent SDS. Sensitivity of F. graminearum strains was tested on PDA amended without or with 0.02% (w/v) congo red. Mycelial growth inhibition was examined after each strain was incubated for 3 days on PDA.

HOG1Δ exhibited increased sensitivity to the cell wall-damaging agent SDS. Sensitivity of F. graminearum strains was tested on PDA amended without or with 0.02% (w/v) congo red. Mycelial growth inhibition was examined after each strain was incubated for 3 days on PDA.

FgSch9Δ HOG1Δ exhibited increased sensitivity to the cell wall-damaging agent SDS. Sensitivity of F. graminearum strains was tested on PDA amended without or with 0.02% (w/v) congo red. Mycelial growth inhibition was examined after each strain was incubated for 3 days on PDA.

ΔFgSch9 showed increased sensitivity to rapamycin. Serial dilutions of conidia suspensions of F. graminearum strains were spotted onto MM or MM containing 0.25 μg ml−1 rapamycin. Colony growth was inspected after 2 days of incubation at 25°C.

Microscopic examination revealed that the mutant hyphae generally branched at a narrower angle than the wild-type progenitor and the complemented strain (Fig. 1B), suggesting FgSch9 plays a role in vegetative reproduction.
After 4 days of incubation in a shaker, ΔFgSch9 produced a similar number of conidia as the wild-type PH-1 (data not shown).
As indicated in Fig. 2C, FgSch9-GFP was localized mainly in the cytoplasm of both conidia and hyphae.
After 20 days of incubation on sterilized wheat kernels, ΔFgSch9 produced significantly lower levels of DON than the wild-type and complemented strains (Fig. 3B).

extension.rangeDisplayName: FgSch9+[WT level] Fusarium graminearum (PH-1) / wild type Triticum aestivum (cv. Zimai 22)

annotations.submitter_comment: After 20 days of incubation on sterilized wheat kernels, ΔFgSch9 produced significantly lower levels of DON than the wild-type and complemented strains (Fig. 3B).
